title: Billy Connolly refuses to allow his Parkinson’s diagnosis to ‘represent’ him
text:
Billy Connolly won’t allow Parkinson’s diagnosis to ‘represent’ him (Picture: IT)

Billy Connolly has admitted he refuses to allow his Parkinson’s diagnosis ‘represent’ him.

The 76-year-old has been suffering from Parkinson’s disease and last performed on stage in 2015 although he is still working on his TV shows.

However, despite being open and public about his diagnosis, the legendary comedian has spoken about wanting to be remembered for being ‘lots of things’ and not just the disease.

‘I refuse to let it represent me, that I have Parkinson’s,’ he said, ‘I’m a lot of things as well as that.’

‘I went to a Parkinson’s Society lunch in Florida and it was all people shaking and f***ing about.

‘I thought, God I’m going to be like that. This isn’t healthy. I don’t find it healthy to swim in Parkinson’s.’

‘I’m a lot of things as well as that,’ he said (Picture: PA)

Speaking to The Telegraph, he admitted that some days Parkinson’s is ‘the first thing I think about when I wake up’.

‘And then you can’t get out of bed. You have to get your wife to pull you out. But some mornings, I think about it the second – they’re good days,’ he shared.

‘And you always manage to get out of bed yourself. And you draw better. And get about your life better.’

Earlier this year Billy bleakly said he felt his life was ‘slipping away’ (Picture: Getty Images)

Earlier this year Billy bleakly said he felt his life was ‘slipping away’ as he battled the incurable disease.

‘My life, it’s slipping away and I can feel it and I should. I’m 75, I’m near the end,’ he said earlier on his documentary Made In Scotland.

‘I’m a damn sight nearer the end than I am the beginning. But it doesn’t frighten me, it’s an adventure and it is quite interesting to see myself slipping away.’

But speaking to the BBC ahead of the release of his new book Tall Tales and Wee Stories, he admitted he is ‘not ready’ to perform again, and that he doesn’t know if he ‘can do it with the state my mind is in’.

‘British comedy is in great shape now. I’d be scared to go on with these [current] guys,’ he said.

‘I’m old, I’m 76 – my hearing, my eyesight, the way I walk, it’s all beginning to fail. It’s just about accepting what it is. You’ve got trouble getting into bed, trouble getting your socks on.’
